title: GOP state leader announces bid to unseat Gluesenkamp Perez in Washington’s 3rd Congressional District
description: Washington state Sen. Braun, the Republican minority leader of the state Senate, will be vying for a competitive, conservative-leaning district in southwestern Washington that was carried by President Donald Trump last year.
content:
CHEHALIS, Wash. — Washington state Sen. John Braun announced Tuesday that he will run next year for the Republican nomination for the U.S. House seat held by Democratic Rep. Marie Gluesenkamp Perez.

Braun, the Republican minority leader of the Democratic-controlled state Senate, will be vying for a competitive, conservative-leaning district in southwestern Washington that was carried by President Donald Trump last year.

Braun said in a statement issued by his campaign that he would work to secure borders and maintain national defense. The statement said Braun is the president of a family-owned manufacturer of emergency vehicles who served in the Navy for 31 years.

“I know how to fight bad policy — and how to craft good policy that makes a difference for people here in Southwest Washington. I look forward to working with President Trump on a positive agenda that gets America back on the right track,” he said.

The six-term Republican who previously held the seat, Jaime Herrera Beutler, did not make it out of the primary that year. Right-wing constituents angry about her vote to impeach Trump instead cast their lot with Joe Kent, a former Army special operations soldier who promoted Trump’s lie that the 2020 election was stolen and touted conspiracy theories about the Jan. 6, 2021, assault on the Capitol.

Gluesenkamp Perez beat Kent by less than a percentage point in 2022. Heading into a rematch with Kent last fall, she was considered one of the most vulnerable members of Congress but won reelection by nearly 4 points.

Gluesenkamp Perez has described political polarization as destructive to democracy and used a nuts-and-bolts approach to governing.

Some progressives in her district have said she has not pushed back hard enough against Trump’s second presidency. But some consultants say her approach could help boost her support among independents and moderate Republicans.

Federal elections filings show that Democrat Brent Hennrich, a former movie theater operations manager who has dismissed Gluesenkamp Perez’s moderation as the wrong approach, and Republican businessman Antony Barran are also running for the seat.
summary: Washington state Sen. John Braun has announced he will run for the Republican nomination for the U.S. House seat held by Democratic Rep. Marie Gluesenkamp Perez. This comes in a competitive, conservative-leaning district in southwestern Washington that was heavily supported by President Donald Trump. Braun, the president of a manufacturer of emergency vehicles, said he would work to secure borders and maintain national defense. The current Republican candidate, Jaime Herrera Beutler, did not make it out of the primary in 2010.
shortSummary: Washington state Sen. John Braun will run for the Republican nomination for the 3rd Congressional District, challenging incumbent Marie Gluesenkamp Perez, focusing on securing borders and national defense.

scraped_sources.text:
U.S. Rep. Marie Gluesenkamp Perez, a Democrat from southwest Washington who has established a reputation for breaking with her party on certain partisan votes, has done so once again.
Gluesenkamp Perez, a second-term member of Congress, was one of just 10 Democrats who voted with the majority Republican party on Thursday to censure Rep. Al Green, a Texas Democrat, for interrupting President Donald Trump during his address to Congress Tuesday.
Green, who was removed from the chamber after his outburst, later said he disrupted the speech to protest Trump’s efforts to slash Medicaid funding. He is the fourth House Democrat to receive the formal reprimand in the past two years, NBC News reported.
Gluesenkamp Perez was the only Democrat from the Pacific Northwest to depart from her party on the vote. All five of Oregon’s Democratic House members — three of whom walked out of the address in protest — voted against the censure.
“When you knowingly break House rules, as Rep. Green did, it shouldn’t be surprising to face consequences,” Gluesenkamp Perez said in a statement to The Oregonian/OregonLive. “Congress should respect the co-equal office of the presidency, regardless of who holds the job, do our constitutional duty, and stop with the theatrics at these events.”
The rural Skamania County resident has long touted her ability to cross party lines on difficult votes, a trait that has vexed fellow Democrats and the liberal among her constituents. In 2023, Gluesenkamp Perez was one of 22 Democrats who voted to censure a fellow caucus member for making pro-Palestinian comments following the Hamas attack on Israel that year.
And while many Democratic members of Congress have committed to actively oppose Trump and his agenda, Gluesenkamp Perez has not strayed from her promise to work with lawmakers of any party.
“Partisan tensions are flaring in the media – but it doesn’t eliminate the need to solve the problems that matter to Southwest Washington and that most of us agree on,” she said in a statement ahead of the presidential address.
Gluesenkamp Perez in November defeated Republican Joe Kent for the second consecutive election to continue representing Washington’s 3rd Congressional District, a Trump-leaning district that includes much of the state’s southwest corner.
— Carlos Fuentes covers state politics and government. Reach him at 503-221-5386 or cfuentes@oregonian.com.

Months into her second term, U.S. Rep. Marie Gluesenkamp Perez of southwest Washington continues to make headlines for her unique approach to politics in today’s hyperpartisan Congress.
But her most recent eye-catching statement in an interview with The New York Times had nothing to do with her self-described centrism. In her conversation with Times columnist and podcast host Ezra Klein, Gluesenkamp Perez said she prefers to not give her 3-year-old son toys to play with.
“You’re talking to a lady who doesn’t give my child toys,” the Democrat said in response to a soundbite of President Donald Trump acknowledging that his tariffs might raise prices on playthings. “I’m a big believer in dirt and string and sticks.”
Gluesenkamp Perez, who in November defeated Republican opponent Joe Kent in a rematch from 2022, told The Oregonian/OregonLive in a follow up statement she believes many adults undervalue “hands-on” experiences that can improve children’s imagination and confidence.
Her own son mostly plays with “real tools, hand-me-downs from his older cousins, and spends a lot of time outside,” she said.
“It’s a mistake to believe that kids need to be entertained — parenting is more fun when a child knows their parents are available, interested, and confident in their child’s inner world and creativity,” Gluesenkamp Perez said.
That sentiment from Gluesenkamp Perez will shock few of her longtime observers. Early in her first term, the auto repair shop co-owner-turned-politician told a crowded town hall that she felt more comfortable on the dirt roads of her district than the streets of Washington D.C. She has also said she prefers not to wear suits to avoid coming across as unapproachable.
Political pundits quickly labelled Gluesenkamp Perez as a freshman member to watch after she narrowly won election in 2022 in a district that has reliably voted for Trump. She has continued to draw national attention for touting her commitment to rural voters in her district, which stretches from coastal communities to timber country deep in the Cascade Mountain Range.
Gluesenkamp Perez’s attitude towards new toys extends to most modern technologies and reflects her general economic philosophy. She described herself as a luddite in early 2023 and told the Times that her stove and washing machine were both built in the 20th century.
The Democrat says her preference for durable, years-old technology reflects her desire to uplift American workers who create such sturdy appliances and goods.
Apart from toys, the recent hour-long interview mostly focused on Gluesenkamp Perez’s approach to a second Trump administration and how her message to voters has differentiated herself from many members of her own party.
While many Democrats at the national level have taken a strong stance against Trump’s international trade policies, Gluesenkamp Perez has offered a quieter, more nuanced response. After all, she has long expressed a commitment to boosting manufacturing and growing jobs in the United States — both of which Trump has cited as primary goals of implementing tariffs.
“At a broader level, tariffs are a tool,” Gluesenkamp Perez said in the Times interview. “A tool can be used destructively, or it can be used productively. And it depends on how it’s wielded.”
Gluesenkamp Perez has taken significant criticism from some of her liberal constituents for statements they view as catering to Republicans. Although she reliably sides with her Democratic colleagues on most votes, she crosses the aisle more than almost any other member of her party, sometimes on controversial issues.
For instance, Gluesenkamp Perez was one of only four Democrats last month who voted for the Safeguard American Voter Eligibility Act, which would have required individuals to present proof of citizenship when registering to vote. Gluesenkamp Perez later said the proposed policy was a “common sense” vote that her constituents supported while many Democrats slammed the bill for potentially creating barriers to voting access.
Gluesenkamp Perez also is quick to criticize members of her own party, saying they are out of touch with voters or rushing to oppose Trump without good reason. For example, she told Klein she has been confused by Democrats’ inconsistent messaging on tariffs and economic philosophy.
“One thing that’s weird is watching the Democratic Party suddenly become the defenders of the stock market and Nasdaq,” Gluesenkamp Perez said. “That’s a weird thing to me.”
— Carlos Fuentes covers state politics and government. Reach him at 503-221-5386 or cfuentes@oregonian.com.

The road to retaining Republican control of the U.S. House of Representatives runs through southwest Washington.
That’s the assertion Republican House Speaker Mike Johnson made at an August fundraiser for Joe Kent, a military veteran endorsed by former President Donald Trump who is running for a second time to represent Washington’s 3rd Congressional District after narrowly losing in 2022.
That year, Democrat Marie Gluesenkamp Perez, who had never held elected office, shocked the political world by beating Kent in a district that had voted for Trump by nearly four percentage points in 2020 and sent a Republican to Congress in six consecutive elections. She prevailed by fewer than 3,000 votes.
“It’s a leaning Republican district. It’s a district that mainstream, normal Republicans should have no problem winning,” said Dean Nielsen, a veteran Seattle-based political consultant. “Joe Kent is different.”
Kent has largely aligned himself with Trump-endorsed policies, including supporting the mass deportation of undocumented immigrants, and received strong support from the district’s most conservative voters. Gluesenkamp Perez, meanwhile, has campaigned on her rural roots and commitment to strengthening the working class and advocating for farmers and small businesses.
The two candidates are preparing for a rematch that experts anticipate could be one of the closest races in the country. Nearby, in Oregon’s 5th District, Democratic state lawmaker Janelle Bynum is challenging incumbent Republican Lori Chavez-DeRemer in another of the nation’s most competitive races.
This year’s race between Gluesenkamp Perez and Kent has received national attention and drawn huge spending, with national groups contributing millions of dollars in hopes of helping their party claim a majority in the U.S. House. Democrats need to net four seats to retake the majority.
“Everybody in the country who follows politics is watching that district,” said Stuart Elway, a longtime pollster based in Seattle.
A moderate Democrat
The 3rd District spans a vast geographic area, stretching from small coastal communities to deep timber country located in the Cascade Mountain Range. The bulk of the population, however, lives in a relatively small area centered around Vancouver, the largest city in Clark County. About two-thirds of registered voters in the district live in that county.
Gluesenkamp Perez, 36, lives in rural Skamania County in the southeastern part of the district and prides herself on being a staunch advocate in Congress for rural, working class people. Prior to entering office, Gluesenkamp Perez helped her husband run an auto shop in Portland, which the two opened after she graduated from Reed College in 2012 and still own.
Despite attending one of the country’s most liberal colleges, Gluesenkamp Perez has solidified herself as a moderate in Congress, co-chairing the Blue Dog Coalition. And she has made national headlines for her willingness to vote against her party when she thinks it will benefit her district.
“There aren’t many Democrats running for Congress who pose in their brochure with a chainsaw in front of an old growth tree,” Elway said.
In a 2023 ranking compiled by The Lugar Center and Georgetown University’s McCourt School of Public Policy, Gluesenkamp Perez ranked fourth among Democrats and 12th overall for most bipartisan members of the 435-member U.S. House of Representatives.
Perhaps the most significant example of Gluesenkamp Perez departing from her party was her vote last year against President Joe Biden’s student loan forgiveness plan. She was one of only two Democrats who voted against the bill, citing its lack of support for career and technical education.
“My district only accounts for 3% of the federally-issued student debt in the state — it was not a good deal for us,” Gluesenkamp Perez told The Oregonian/OregonLive. “I’m not here to score points for a political team. I’m here to fight for our way of life in southwest Washington.”
Gluesenkamp Perez has championed legislation to support small businesses and farmers. Last month, she introduced a bill that would establish zero-interest loans for farmers to buy land designated for specialty crops. Last year, she voted against advancing the farm bill out of the House Agriculture Committee, saying that it did not go far enough in supporting family farms.
Gluesenkamp Perez has used her platform to bring several powerful federal officials, including Biden senior adviser Mitch Landrieu and Secretary of Transportation Pete Buttigieg, to give them an up-close look at the district.
Three months into her term, she took U.S. Small Business Administration director Isabel Guzman to a Vancouver climbing gym so she could hear about the owner’s experience applying for pandemic-era federal grants and brought Xochitl Torres-Small, the undersecretary of the federal Department of Agriculture, to a rural property to hear from farmers about their biggest needs.
“A lot of my colleagues seem to think they can just send an email and that will yield results for their community,” Gluesenkamp Perez said. “I know that it takes work to make our issues human-scale to the federal government. You got to bring them out here and talk about things in concrete terms.”
Gluesenkamp Perez’s focus on her constituents, experts say, is likely the reason that she has racked up endorsements from numerous labor unions and trade groups. Her long list of supporters include the state’s largest unions representing police and sheriffs, firefighters, farmers and teachers.
“She’s done a lot of outreach and really stepped up in a way that a lot of people in Congress have not in the past,” said Lorne Bulling, political director for Ironworkers Local 29, which represents ironworkers in Oregon and southwest Washington. “She’s been incredibly accessible and always has made time.”
Trump-endorsed challenger
Kent’s polarizing views have made him a divisive candidate since he first ran in 2022.
The 44-year old from Yacolt, a small town 30 miles northeast of Vancouver, has a compelling background that resonates in a district that reveres its veterans. Kent served in the U.S. Army for two decades before becoming a field operative for the CIA. He then worked as a foreign policy adviser for the Trump administration. His first wife, a Navy cryptologic technician, was killed in a 2019 bombing in Syria.
If elected, Kent said his top priorities would include cutting unnecessary government spending, securing the southern U.S. border and imposing large tariffs on foreign imports, all Trump priorities.
“Everything these guys have tried has failed,” Kent said, referring to Democrats and the Biden administration, during a packed September town hall in Vancouver. “The economy is being destroyed because of their policies. The border’s wide open. Fentanyl is flooding the district. We’re on the cusp of a major nuclear exchange and World War III on multiple fronts on the world stage, the list goes on.”
Kent has received strong support from the district’s most conservative voters. “What he is focused on is being a Trump Republican, and that has not changed” since he ran in 2022, said Mark Stephan, a political science professor at Washington State University in Vancouver.
Kent has shifted his stance on some controversial issues, including abortion. Kent said in 2022 that he fully supported a national abortion ban, calling abortion a “stain on our democracy.” He now says he supports each state enacting its own laws.
Kent declined multiple interview requests from The Oregonian/OregonLive through his campaign manager and didn’t respond to a list of emailed questions.
When Kent ran for the seat in 2022, The Associated Press reported that he had close ties with several known right-wing extremist groups and activists. Kent hired a campaign consultant that year who was a member of the Proud Boys, a far-right extremist group. Kent was also an ally of Joey Gibson, the founder of a Christian nationalist group that held demonstrations in Portland that often resulted in physical confrontations with left-wing activists.
After facing backlash in 2022 for working on social media strategy with internet personality Nick Fuentes, who has espoused white supremacist beliefs, Kent appeared on a podcast to address the controversy. While he sought to distance himself from Fuentes, he said, “I don’t think there’s anything wrong with there being a white people special interest group.”
Trump also received criticism for dining with Fuentes at Mar-a-Lago in November 2022.
Nielsen, the Seattle political consultant, said Kent’s extreme views and ties have likely cost him the support of some moderate voters. “Joe Kent really turns off a lot of moderate voters and even more traditional conservatives that don’t really approve of the MAGA style,” he said.
Kent’s supporters have tried to downplay those ties to far-right groups and individuals. “It was a lot of (Kent being) guilty by association,” said Jim Walsh, a Republican state lawmaker and chair of the Washington State Republican Party. “As I understand it, he knew some people who were connected to the Proud Boys.”
Along with his endorsement from Trump, Kent has support from several conservative members of Congress and from the county and state Republican party chapters. However, his campaign website does not provide a list of his endorsements like most campaigns do. Kent’s campaign manager didn’t respond to an email asking for a full list of endorsements.
“He’s genuine, he believes in work and in self-reliance, self-actualization,” Walsh said. “These are things that southwest Washington values.”
Trading blows
Gluesenkamp Perez and Kent have embraced starkly different campaigning strategies, a contrast that was on full display Wednesday at their first debate, held in Longview.
Gluesenkamp Perez says her proven commitment to the district, including its rural, working class voters, makes her worthy of another term. Kent, meanwhile, focused on national issues, criticizing Democrats’ handling of the U.S.-Mexico border and the economy.
“We actually saw working class wages rise under President Trump. We can easily bring that back,” Kent said. “President Trump just needs a Congress that’s actually going to support him and not fight him.”
Federal data shows that wages steadily increased during much of Trump’s administration, following a trend that began under President Barack Obama. But the most rapid increases came during the pandemic when lower wage workers were disproportionately impacted by layoffs.
“You can hear clearly that this is about partisan politics for him. It’s about delivering a Republican majority,” Gluesenkamp Perez responded. “I’m not here for that. I’m here for us.”
Since Gluesenkamp Perez entered Congress last year, Kent has aggressively attacked her voting record. He has criticized her support for a Biden-sponsored bill that blocked local policies restricting transgender students from using the bathroom of their choice. He has also opposed her backing of the Interstate Bridge replacement between Portland and Vancouver, arguing instead for the construction of a new bridge farther down the Columbia River that he says would alleviate congestion while saving costs.
“It’s time to send someone to Washington, D.C., who’s not going to prioritize simple party politics, the military industrial complex and big pharma infringements on our basic civil liberties,” Kent said. “It’s time to actually represent the people.”
In defense of her voting record, Gluesenkamp Perez said that she has always acted in the district’s best interests. “If he’s saying that my accomplishments and my values, my record in D.C. are small, then he’s saying transportation for rural veterans is small ... supporting the timber industry and our paper and pulp industries is small,” she said. “Those things aren’t small. They’re our values.”
Political experts and insiders say they aren’t surprised by the differing tactics.
“Republicans are trying to talk about the border all the time. The border and the economy are the two issues they think they have,” pollster Elway said. On the other hand, Gluesenkamp Perez is “obviously very attuned to her district, very oriented toward the local constituency, much less so on the national issues. She’s trying to localize the race and he’s trying to nationalize it.”
While the 3rd District race largely fell under the national radar in 2022, it hasn’t this time around.
Gluesenkamp Perez had raised more than $6.7 million as of mid-July, and Kent had raised $1.4 million as of mid-August, according to filings with the Federal Election Commission. The candidates will report updated campaign finance data later this month.
National groups have spent millions of dollars to flood the Portland media market with attack ads against both candidates. Outside groups have dropped more than $4 million to oppose Kent and almost $1.9 million to oppose Gluesenkamp Perez, according to Open Secrets, a nonprofit that tracks money in politics.
The Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee has devoted a whopping $2.7 million to attack Kent while the House Majority PAC, the largest super PAC helping to elect Democrats to the U.S. House, has spent $1.15 million against him, according to Open Secrets.
The National Republican Congressional Committee has allotted nearly $1.8 million to attack Gluesenkamp Perez, Open Secrets reported.
“The House is on the knife’s edge, and this race is probably the closest of any of them,” Elway said. “So from their standpoint, they’ve got to spend that money. ... It could come down to this one.”

First-term Democratic U.S. Rep. Marie Gluesenkamp Perez has defeated Republican Joe Kent in the race to represent southwest Washington in Congress.
As of 6 p.m. Thursday, Washington election officials reported that Gluesenkamp Perez led by 51.3% to 48.3%, a difference of 11,000 votes. That margin has eroded just slightly since election night.
It compares to her winning edge of fewer than 5,000 votes in 2022.
The fact that Gluesenkamp Perez has a glide path to victory, while Kent lacks a plausible path to winning, is primarily because the largest share by far of untallied ballots are in Clark County, where roughly two thirds of 3rd District voters live. The county still has an estimated 40,000 votes to count, according to state election officials, and so far 56% of Clark County’s votes have gone her way. There are negligible numbers of outstanding ballots in other of the district’s counties, according to reports from county election offices.
In 2022, Gluesenkamp Perez, who had never held elected office, shocked the political world by beating Kent in a district that had voted for former President Donald Trump by nearly four percentage points two years earlier. Experts expected this year’s race in Washington’s 3rd Congressional District to again be one of the closest in the country.

The race received national attention and drew huge spending, with national groups contributing millions in hopes of helping their party claim a majority in the U.S. House.
The balance of power in the U.S. House has yet to be determined. Democrats needed to net four seats to take control of that chamber. As of Thursday night, Republicans needed to win seven more seats for control and Democrats needed 18. Competitive races throughout the country had yet to be called.
Kent largely aligned himself with positions embraced by Trump, including supporting the mass deportation of undocumented immigrants, and received strong support from the district’s most conservative voters. Gluesenkamp Perez, meanwhile, campaigned on her rural roots and commitment to strengthening the working class and advocating for farmers and small businesses.
“I’m deeply grateful for this vote of confidence in the work I’ve done to set aside national politics and represent our community in Washington, D.C.,” Gluesenkamp Perez said in a Thursday statement.
“Like two years ago, pundits made a fundamental mistake by viewing this race through a partisan lens,” she said. “Our community has never seen ourselves this way, and it’s not how we evaluate who merits our vote for Congress.”
Gluesenkamp Perez lives in rural Skamania County in the southeastern part of the district and prides herself on being a staunch advocate in Congress for rural, working class people. Prior to entering office, Gluesenkamp Perez helped her husband run an auto shop in Portland, which the two opened after she graduated from Reed College in 2012, and still own.
Despite attending one of the country’s most liberal colleges, Gluesenkamp Perez has solidified herself as a moderate in Congress, co-chairing the Blue Dog Coalition. And she has made national headlines for her willingness to vote against her party when she thinks it will benefit her district.
In a 2023 ranking compiled by The Lugar Center and Georgetown University’s McCourt School of Public Policy, Gluesenkamp Perez ranked fourth among Democrats and 12th overall for most bipartisan members of the 435-member U.S. House of Representatives.
“I think 90% of people in southwest Washington agree on 90% of things, regardless of their political identity,” Gluesenkamp Perez said in her statement. “We are not the sort of place where we define ourselves and our neighbors by our bumper stickers.”
She has also brought several powerful federal officials, including Biden senior adviser Mitch Landrieu and Secretary of Transportation Pete Buttigieg, to the district.
Gluesenkamp Perez’s focus on her constituents, experts said, is likely the reason she racked up endorsements from labor unions and trade groups. Her long list of supporters included the state’s largest unions representing police and sheriffs, firefighters, farmers and teachers.
Kent served in the U.S. Army for two decades before becoming a field operative for the CIA. He then worked as a foreign policy adviser for the Trump administration. Kent’s first wife, a Navy cryptologic technician, was killed in a 2019 bombing in Syria.
If elected, he promised to cut unnecessary government spending, secure the southern U.S. border and impose large tariffs on foreign imports, all Trump priorities. Along with an endorsement from Trump, he was endorsed by several conservative members of Congress and the county and state Republican party chapters.
Gluesenkamp Perez had raised nearly $10.7 million and Kent had raised $2.3 million as of mid-October, according to federal filings. Outside groups dropped nearly $10.3 million to oppose Kent and almost $6.2 million to oppose Gluesenkamp Perez, according to Open Secrets, a nonprofit that tracks money in politics.
